text: A small caveman community made up of five large caves, al facing out towards a crackling fire. Slack-jawed, yet strong and confident CAVEMEN stumble abo dragging haunches of meat, pounding the dirt with sticks, dragging the women. WE PAN OVER to a small cave. Not even really a cave at al but a crack in the rocks barely large enough to sleep in. Stepping out of this "cave" is a small, weak, nerdy-looki caveman. The chief caveman, set apart by the large mallet he wield steps towards the fire and grunts loudly to mark the beginning of a caveman meeting. "Loser caveman" steps forward apprehensively, only to be with laughter from the other cavemen. "Loser caveman" sig and shrinks back into his sad, little cave, watching them from the shadows.
(grunting; subtitled) Me see beast today. Beast scary. Beast danger for caveman.
The rest of the cavemen look nervous.
If caveman kill beast? Caveman safe. Caveman have food.
The cavemen grunt in understanding.
Who kill beast?
The cavemen grunt amongst themselves. The toughest of the bunch steps forward, pounds his chest and grunts.
Grob kill beast. Good Grob.
The chief notices "loser caveman" watching from a distanc
Loser want kill beast?
All the cavemen turn and laugh at the "loser caveman".
Loser kill nothing!
All the cavemen laugh hysterically.
Look at Loser cave! So small!
Loser dumb!
Fuck that guy!
All the cavemen pick up rocks and begin throwing them at "loser caveman", who dives out of his cave and runs aroun the camp, dodging their blows.

Everyone in the village is asleep. Everyone, that is, but "loser caveman" who sleeps uncomfortably in his tiny litt cave, tossing and turning, unable to get comfortable. A stirring in the trees causes "loser caveman" to sit upright. There's something outside of the village. Someth big. Suddenly a GIANT TUSKED BOAR pushes through the trees and stands, looking quite menacing, not ten yards from the village fire. "Loser caveman" is practically shaking with fear. The boa makes eye-contact with "loser caveman" and charges direct towards his tiny little cave. The giant boar runs head first into the cave opening, but opening is too small for the beast to fit its head inside "Loser caveman" screams like a girl. The boar backs up to strike again -- this one sure to be end of "loser caveman" -- when a large boulder, knocked l by the Boar's first hit, tumbles down and lands smack on Boar's head, killing it instantly. The entire village runs out to see what has happened. The "Loser caveman" stumbles out of the cave and dusts himsel off. The chief steps forward.
The beast! It dead!
Hey, look at loser! He almost die! Look he scared!
Everyone laughs. The Chief looks towards Loser, standing nervously near the corpse of the Giant Tusked Boar.
Loser, what happen?
(SHAMEFULLY) The Beast, it came at me. It smash my cave.

Everyone laughs hysterically. WE PAN over the many laughi faces, pointing and hooting at loser caveman's cowardice. watch as the "loser caveman's" face turns bright red, the veins in his neck pop out and his fists clench up tightly SUDDENLY WE FLY into the caveman's skull, traveling throu his cerebral cortex and towards the frontal lobe of his small, homo erectus brain. Sparks are flying back and for across his brain as his synapses fire in rapid succession There is a SMALL EXPLOSION. We fly back out of "loser caveman's" skull -- his face contorted in rage. He interrupts everyone's laughter.
Hold on one minute!
Everyone stops laughing.
Loser wasn't finished.
Loser caveman stands up straight and tall -- all of a sud the Bruce Willis of cavemen.
After beast smash cave, Loser look at beast and say, "not on Loser's watch." Loser grab rock on ground, lift above head and smash it down... right onto motherfucker's head.
The entire village gasps.
Loser kill beast.
Now fuck off, Loser going back to sleep.
The chief steps forward ominously, then proclaims:
Loser kill beast! Loser caveman hero!
Loser steps forward, grabs the prettiest of all cavewomen drags her towards his cave as the entire village erupts i cheer.
The world's first lie. A monumental occasion in the history of mankind.
That lowly caveman who stumbled upon the ability to lie went on to become chief of his village, married dozens of cavewomen, and passed on the lying gene to hundreds of newborn cave-children.

Over time lying spread throughout the world, sparking the eventual birth of imagination itself, story- telling, religion, and the oh-so- important polite lie, as in, "Oh Patty, have you lost weight? You look fantastic."

The world would be a very different place if events had gone otherwise on that prolific, Paleolithic eve. If not for that night, man would have never acquired the ability to lie to himself and to others.
A world without lying would be a world without dreams. A world without pretense. A world without fiction. A world without flattery. A world very unlike our own.
The film rewinds about thirty seconds, to the point where chief asked what happened with "loser caveman" and the bo
Loser, what happen?
(SHAMEFULLY) The Beast, it came at me. It smash my cave.

AGAIN WE FLY into the caveman's skull, traveling through homo erectus brain. Sparks are flying back and forth acro his brain as his synapses fire in rapid succession... But this time there's no explosion. We fly back out of "loser caveman's" skull -- his face contorted in rage. The rage slowly fades and Loser just stands there, everyo in the camp waiting for him to say something.
Rock fall on beast. Loser do nothing. I think Loser even soil bear pants. (pause; sniffing) Loser smell bad.
Everyone falls onto the ground laughing hysterically.
Loser biggest loser ever! Caveman, throw rocks at loser!
Everyone in the camp joins in on another round of throwin rocks at "loser caveman" as he runs around the camp, terrified and miserable.
A completely indistinguishable Los Angeles mid-rent apart complex. MARK BELLISON pulls up in his early nineties Volvo, parks enters.
Mark (40's), average to semi-handsome, twists and turns through stucco hallways. He knocks on apartment "9C". JENNIFER MCDOOGLES opens, her face flushed. She's beautif
Hi. You're early. I was just masturbating.
That makes me think of your vagina. I'm Mark, how are you?
A little frustrated at the moment. Also equally depressed and pessimistic about our date tonight. I'm Jennifer.
I hope this date ends in sex.
Not me. I don't find you attractive. Come on in.
Mark enters.
Jennifer's apartment is new-adult, as if she just found o she was an adult yet hasn't had the time or the money to complete the transition.
I need to finish getting ready. While doing that I might realize I'm still horny and try to finish masturbating without you hearing.
Jennifer heads towards the bathroom. Mark stands alone in living room, looking around.
(shouting to her) I feel awkward and I regret being early.
(shouting back) Yeah, I'm disappointed you're early and not really looking forward to tonight in general, but the thought of being alone the rest of my life scares both my mother and I equally.
It's completely silent for a long beat. Mark looks around then sits on her couch.
(shouting to her) I have an erection now because I assume you began masturbating once we stopped talking.
More silence.

(shouting to her) I'm embarrassed because I think the restaurant I've made reservations at might not be expensive enough or hip enough to impress you, but it was the best I could do because I don't make very much money. You see, I'm forty years old and have no real financial assets to speak of, I've never owned a home, and never had a significant relationship. My boss even told me today that I'm most likely going to get fired tomorrow and...
Jennifer enters the room and Mark stops talking.
I just masturbated.
That makes me very horny.
Shall we go?
Sure.
Mark stands up. Jennifer picks up her purse and opens the door.
After you.
Mark and Jennifer drive in silence for a beat.
I'm only doing this as a favor for my cousin Greg. He keeps begging me to go out on a date with you. He says you're funny.
Greg's a good friend.
Where are we eating tonight?
A cute little place called La Bonisera in West Hollywood.
You obviously don't have very much money but that's not necessarily a deal breaker.
I have very little money.
I also don't really care about a guy who knows all the latest, hippest restaurants.
I don't know any of them.

In fact, there are very few things in life that I care about all that much. The only things I have to offer myself or anyone else are my good looks and my affected sense of quirkiness which artistically inclined men interpret as intellect.

JENNIFER (cont'd) In fact, I think my best trait is the fact that I've made very few mistakes: socially, academically, financially or romantically. I take very few risks and therefore lead a relatively happy and light-hearted existence. Mostly though, I'm a kind, sweet person with the potential of genuinely becoming a vital and interesting human being the day I take the energy I expend on hyper self-reflexivity and apply it to actual action in the reality of my life.
I found that boring and started thinking about this place's fish tacos.
The Volvo pulls up in front of the restaurant and the val parking guy opens Jennifer's door.
I'm extremely bored.
Hello.
The valet parking guy hands Mark a ticket.
They enter the quaint Mexican restaurant.
This isn't as nice as I remember it.
What are we going to talk about?
They approach the hostess.
(to Jennifer) I'm threatened by you.
Two, please.
Of course, come with me.
The hostess seats them in the midst of the semi-crowded restaurant. A young, awkward waiter approaches.
I'm very embarrassed that I work here. Hi.
Hello.
Hello.
(to Jennifer) And you're pretty and that only makes me feel worse. Can I get you two started on some drinks?
I'll have a Budweiser.
I'll start with your Mango Margarita and probably have three more drinks by the end of the night.
Excellent. (to Mark) She's out of your league.
Yup.
The waiter leaves. Jennifer and Mark peruse their menus. woman screams out from a table on the other side of the r
(SCREAMING) All of a sudden I got EXTREMELY angry!
No one in the restaurant reacts.
I'm going to ask you some questions about your life because that's what you do, but I'll only really listen to about half of what you're saying.
Jennifer nods.
How do you spend your days?
I get up at eight in the morning because the noise from my alarm clock interrupts my sleep, so I lean over and...
That's a little more specific than I expected.
Well what did you want to know?
Do you have a job?
Yes.
What job do you have?
I have a job at an office.
What do you do?
Just typing and filing and stuff.
Do you enjoy it?

No. But I enjoy the end result of the job which is money. And the hours are pretty good for the amount of money I make, which I spend on things I like, such as clothes, hiking, drinking -- even though I know it's bad for me.
JENNIFER (cont'd) (PAUSE) But I'd rather just get all the money and not work for the results.
Sure. Tell me more. I'm trying to get a little insight into you.

Well you already know a lot about me. You know I'm good looking because... well... here I am. You know I'm successful because you've seen my apartment and the clothes I'm wearing. And you know I'm happy because I'm smiling.
Jennifer smiles brightly.
Are you always happy?
Usually. Some days I stay in bed eating and crying.
Sure.
The waiter returns with their drinks.
(hands beer to Mark) Here you go. (hands drink to Jennifer) I had a sip of this.
Okay.
Do you guys know what you want or do you need a moment?
I'm ready.
I'll have a caesar salad with chicken because I think I'm fat but I also think I deserve something that tastes good.
I'll have the fish taco's because I had them once here and it's all I know.
Excellent, I'll get those both started for you.
The waiter leaves. Jennifer's cell phone rings from insid her purse.
Sorry, one second.
She pulls out her cell phone and checks it.
It's my mother, this won't take long. Probably checking in on our date.
Jennifer answers the phone. She talks openly and in plain view of Mark.

Hello? Yes, I'm with him right now. No, not very attractive. No, doesn't make much money. He's all right though. Seems nice. Kind of funny. A bit fat. Funny little snub nose. No, I won't be sleeping with him tonight. Nope, probably not even a kiss. Okay, you too. Bye.
Jennifer hangs up.
Sorry about that.
Don't think twice. How is your mom?
She's all right.
Fantastic.
Both of their plates are now empty. Three empty Margarita glasses sit in front of Jennifer.
The waiter approaches with the bill and places it down in middle of the table.
(to Jennifer) If I give you my number will you call me?
No.
Mark walks Jennifer to the front door of her apartment complex.
Thanks for going on this date with me. You're way, way out of my league and I know you were just doing it as a favor to Greg, and that most likely I'll never hear from you again.
I actually had a better time than I thought I'd have, but I won't know for sure how I feel about you until I'm less drunk.
Give me a call if you still like me once you're sober.
I might.
Mark leans in for a kiss. Jennifer kisses him on the chee and goes inside.
Thanks for kissing me on the cheek, I know you didn't have to do that and....
Jennifer waves and heads inside.
(shouting after her) ... you're very pretty. Thank you!

Mark plops into bed in his boxers. His bedroom is bland, uninspired and completely furnished by the cheapest stuff found in an IKEA catalogue. Mark flips on the TV and gets under the covers. A commerc comes on TV.
A man in a suit stands next to a single can of coke resti on a small table.

Hi, I'm Jim and I'm the spokesperson for the Coca-Cola company. I'm here today to ask you to continue buying coke. I'm sure it's a drink you've been drinking for years, and if you still enjoy it, I'd like to remind you to buy it again sometime soon. It's basically just brown sugar water, we haven't changed the ingredients much lately, so there's nothing new about it I can say. We changed the can around a little bit. See, the colors here are a little different, and we even put a polar bear on it for the kids. Also, coke is very high in sugar, can lead to obesity in children and adults who don't sustain a healthy diet, and has a Ph acidity level high enough to dissolve teeth and bones over extended periods of time. Coke also works great at removing corrosion from car batteries and loosening rusted bolts. So that's it, it's coke. Everyone knows it. It's very famous. I'm Jim, I work for coke, and I'm asking you to not stop buying coke. That's all. Thanks.
INSERT: Coke logo with tagline: "It's Coke. It's very famous." Mark falls asleep with the TV on.
Mark's alarm clock blares. Groggily he rises and sighs deeply. He has nothing to look forward to today. Or any d
Mark stands in his building's elevator. The doors open an FRANK, mid-forties and bald, enters.
Hi Mark. How's it going?
Not so good. Last night I went on a date with a girl I've had a crush on for years who will most likely never call me again and I'm pretty sure I'm going to get fired today. You?
I spent the whole night throwing up pain killers because I'm too afraid to take enough to kill myself.
The elevator doors open on the lobby. Mark nods at Frank.
See you tomorrow.
Bye.

As Mark drives to work we take in a bit of his world. A homeless man stands on a street corner with a sign that reads: "I don't understand why I'm homeless and all of yo are not." A business man talking loudly into his cell phone pulls u next to mark at a red light.
I'm not talking to anyone on my cell phone. I only want people to assume I'm very busy.
At another red light Mark eavesdrops on a couple having a loud argument in front of a coffee shop.
I woke up this morning and realized that, not only do I not love you, but that the thought of touching you sickens me.
The more you hate me the more I fall in love with you.

A Bus passes in front of Mark's car. ANGLE ON: The bus ad simply shows a can of Pepsi, and rea "Pepsi. When they don't have Coke." A car honks behind Mark. The man leans out of his car and yells at Mark.
Move it, fatty!
Mark drives forward, waving to the man apologetically as man zooms past him.

Mark parks his car and walks towards a large office build The sign on the building reads: "LECTURE FILMS MOTION PIC STUDIOS -- We Film Someone Telling You About Things That Happened." In front of the building is a man in a suit standing on h briefcase with his tie around his head, screaming.
This isn't natural! None of this is natural! We're all animals! This doesn't feel right! Why am I wearing clothes? How can you people live like this? Where did all this concrete come from?!
Mark walks right by him. A woman in a business suit stops on his way through the front door.
I don't want to go in there today. I just don't. You know?
Mark nods understandingly and enters the building.

As Mark walks through the lobby we get a brief glimpse of some of the movie posters lining the wall: "The Holocaust "The Death of the Dinosaurs", "Napoleon", "The Civil War" Each poster shows a different austere man sitting in a ch holding a script in his lap, with a title above his head. posters are extremely boring. All of Lecture Films' productions are written, filmed and edited right here on this very lot. In fact, this building is where Lecture Films' talented writers scour through the world's past events, searching for the most entertaining, dramatic and even hilarious moments of world history, which are then turned into scripts, handed over to our world-famous Readers, and filmed for your viewing pleasure.
The whole tour "oohs". The tour guide walks over towards large flat-screen television embedded into the wall.
If you'll just follow me over to this monitor you'll get a sneak peak at Lecture Film's upcoming summer's blockbuster: "Napoleon 1812 to 1813."
Everyone "oohs" again. Mark, curious as well, stops to wa the trailer with the tour. ANGLE ON: TV SCREEN. A black screen.
Coming this summer from Lecture Films Motion Picture Studios. Written by Oscar winning screenwriter Rob Marlowe.
INTERCUT Mark scowling at this name.
And starring Oscar winning Reader Nathan Goldfrappe, comes the epic sequel to last year's most talked about film: "Napoleon 1810 to 1811". Prepare for the adventure.
The black fades to NATHAN GOLDFRAPPE, a middle-aged auste man sitting before a fire in a velvet smoking jacket, hol a script.
(READING) And so Napoleon invaded Russia with a brute force of nearly seven hundred thousand men behind him armed with muskets and supported by canon brigades.

I love these films. Saves me reading the book.

Napoleon 1812 to 1813. Coming this summer from Lecture Films.

Now let's head to editing bay where we can watch....

Okay, I'll be in my office.
Okay, I'll be searching for new jobs on Craigslist.

Mark's office is completely boring and unremarkable, much like his apartment. There's a knock on his door. ANTHONY enters, looking very much the boss in his expensi suit, yet nervous and fearful as well.
Wow, you look really depressed today. That's going to make this so much harder.
Anthony, don't fire me.

Mark, the 1300's are boring. Nothing interesting happened in that century. Nobody cares about the post-Roman, pre-enlightenment era. The last few scripts you turned in were depressing.
They were about the black plague! It's the 1300's Anthony, what else am I going to write about!
It's not totally your fault, Mark. You got stuck with a bad century.
No! I can make it work!

Give it up Mark, it's not like something new is going to have happened in the 1300's. At Lecture Films we're no longer interested in searching through the less well- known historical periods for great events, we just want to take the big name Reader's of the day and have them read the historical events that people know and love: the holocaust, D-day, the birth of electricity. These are the stories people want to see, because they know them. They find comfort in them.
Anthony pauses.
Do you think I could come back and do this tomorrow? I just got very nervous about firing you. I don't do well with confrontation.
Is there anyway you could do it now? I'd rather not put it off.
Anthony thinks for a moment, struggling to find the coura
(MEEKLY) You're fired?
Damn.

ANGLE ON: MARK'S COMPUTER -- The email reads: "I woke up morning, sober, and realized that, while I did enjoy your company, based on your looks, your financial situation an your position in life, I have no interest in you romantically. I'm just too far out of your league. --

She's a really good writer, too.

I loathed almost every minute I worked for you.
I often fantasized about you naked.
What are you going to do now?
I have no idea. But I have very little hope for the future.
I don't have much hope for you either, but I wish you good luck.
Bye, Shelley.
Bye, Mark.

So they fucking fired you, huh dipshit? I always knew the Black Plague would never work as a movie. Guess the 1300's were as much of a loser as you are.
Please don't make me feel worse. Or actually whatever, go ahead, I don't think I could possibly feel worse.

I fucking always hated you. You're a shitty writer assigned to a shitty century and you're a little man bitch. But I was always threatened by you because I knew there was something different about you that I didn't understand and I fucking hate things I don't understand. But you will always be a loser and I will always be more successful than you in nearly every way. That's just the way it is. And Shelley calls you an ass fag behind your back.
Well, now I feel worse.
Rob storms off. Mark slinks into the elevator and hangs h head in shame as the doors close.
Mark enters the building.
Mark walks up to the front desk to find a young reception
Are you looking to abandon an elderly person?
I already have. Martha Bellison. I'm her grandson.
Ooh, it's good you're here. She's not doing well. You should say your final goodbyes today.
You say that every time I'm here.
She's at the top of our death pool.
Mark walks down the hall, passing different elderly peopl who reach out to him.
You look like my dead son.
Life gets worse with each passing minute.
I'm on pills that make everything orange.
Mark opens a door and enters.
An elderly woman in a light blue robe sits on the side of bed, with her back to Mark, staring at the wall only inch from her face.
Oh Grandma, that is so depressing. Come on, at least stare at the ceiling or something.
Mark takes his grandmother by the hand and steers her to other side of her bed.
The television is broken.
The television isn't broken. You probably sat on the remote and changed it to channel two again.
Mark flicks on the TV with the remote. Static fills the screen. He changes the channel and a picture comes into v
See, you had it on the wrong channel. It needs to be on channel three in order for the satellite to work.
I don't understand anything you just said and that makes me scared and angry.
MARK
I can't understand what it feels like to be you so it just irritates me and makes me think you're stupid. But I also love you and wish things were better for you. MARTHA
I do too. MARK
Grandma, I lost my job today. I'm forty years old. I'm completely alone and I've got absolutely no prospects for anything. MARTHA
I'm sorry, Mark. Things aren't any better for me here. I can't afford most of my medication, I'm very alone and I forget more and more every day. MARK
I'm just so tired of life. Why does life have to be so... what's the word? Don't you sometimes wish you could change things? Don't you sometimes wish you weren't such a loser? MARTHA
I don't think I'm a loser. MARK
Of course you're a loser, grandma. Our family is made up of losers. We're all poor, we're all average looking, we're all only moderately intelligent, we're all lonely and unloved. MARTHA

Well, we're poor because we weren't born with money and it's very hard to make enough money in a single lifetime to move from one social class to another. We're only moderately intelligent because there's been a lot of inbreeding in our lineage. And we're only lonely and unloved right now. Remember, I've had two husbands I loved very much in my lifetime. (MORE)
MARTHA (cont'd) And maybe one day you'll have a wife that you love very much too.
Yeah, but I'm not talking about the past, Grandma. I'm talking about right now. And right now we're both losers, Grandma. We're both shitty, shitty losers. Don't you know that?
I suppose we are. But things could be worse. We could be homeless.
I'd rather be dead than be homeless. That's why I need to get out there and find a job. If I have to be homeless, I'm going to kill myself.
Well that's sad. I love you, Mark. Good luck finding a job!
I love you too, Grandma.

Oops.
Mark and his friend GREG (40'S), an even less attractive, less interesting and less intelligent version of Mark, ar bellied up the bar with half empty beers in front of them
I'll start looking for a job tomorrow.
Lately I don't like Indian people. (PAUSE) I don't like white people even more though. I fucking hate white people. I fucking hate people.

Third cousin. She's hot right?
Very.

It felt nice to go out with someone that pretty. Like for just one moment I experienced what it would be like to be the type of person someone like that would date. It felt good. Your life is still better than mine.

A sad beat.
Lately I've been crying in my sleep and waking up in a pool of urine.

So, what are you going to do now?

I'm going to go now. You're seriously depressing me. I really wish I was cool enough to have a better friend than you.

Mark and Greg almost roll into the pool they're laughing hard. The people on the other side of the fence aren't laughing: "Who's my real mother?", "This explains so much "Dad, why didn't you tell me?"
I don't know why we're laughing. It's really probably very sad for those people.
I'm gettin' a beer.
Mark hobbles up and walks into the house. Moments later h emerges with two cokes.
Out of beer. Just Coke.
Mark tosses Greg a Coke and sits down on his chaise loung cracking open his Coke and taking a sip.
I want to do something big again. Like telling the people what happens when they die. That felt good. I gotta do something big like that again.

Mark looks down at his can of Coke. CLOSE ON COKE CAN: The warning label is extremely long an written in very small type. It starts with, "COKE IS VERY FOR YOU. The following are diseases, physical ailments an general health issues that coke might cause:" The label then goes on to list dozens of ailments. Mark's eyes scan down to the very bottom of the label where it s simply, "If you still want to drink Coke, do so at your o risk." Mark looks over to find Greg staring at the depressing la as well.
Ugh, this shit is so bad for you. I really shouldn't drink this.
Mark stares at this label for a moment, thinking. With hi hand he covers everything on the label except for "Please Enjoy Coke." He smiles widely.
Hey, Greg. What if I told you that drinking Coke was good for you?
Greg turns to him, his face full of hope.
And not just Coke. But all the delicious foods you're not supposed to eat. What if they were all of a sudden really, really good for you?
It would be the happiest day of my life.

A dozen high powered executives from all over the globe s around a massive board room table. The head seat at the t is unoccupied. They mumble back and forth to each other, unsure why they there. Mark bursts into the room in a suit, looking very manicur

Mark hits a button and a projection screen comes down on far wall. Mark starts a slide show.
Up until now, all products sold worldwide have warning labels printed on them. Warnings like these.

SERIES OF SLIDES: We see the same warning we just saw on Coke can, a commercial jet with "This Plane Might Crash - Four Of Our Other Ones Did" printed on its side, a car dashboard light reading "This Car will Ignite Upon Impact Always", and a sticker on a grocery store package of grou meat that reads "Injected with hormones that make it tast better -- but will eventually give you cancer".
As you can see, a lot of these products can be very depressing. They remind people of all the horrible things that can happen to them in life. People hate thinking about horrible things.
Yeah, but they have to know those things.
EXECUTIVE #2 (cont'd) They have to be able to protect themselves. I don't want to hurt anyone. Especially now that I know about the "bad place".
Everyone in the room shudders.
Hear me out, fellas. Allow me to introduce you to the future of your companies.
Mark changes the slide to a can of coke that simple reads "Coke -- Tastes Great! And It's Good For You!" Everyone in the room "ahhhs".

The executives all squint their eyes.
But this one is healthy! And it tastes great!
Do you have any samples?
Guys, it's the same Coke on the inside. I've just changed the outside.
(REVELATION) Somehow by changing the outside, he's also changed the inside!
Everyone "aaahs" in understanding. Mark sighs and changes slide to that of a commercial airliner with the words "Completely Safe" writing on the outside.
Oh, thank goodness. I've always hated flying!
Me too!
What an invention! How did you do it?
I didn't do anything, guys. I made this on my computer last night. The plane is exactly the same as it was before.
Nobody in the room gets it.
That's the only plane I'll ever fly on again!
That's the point here guys. With these new advertising strategies, people will buy your products with abandon.
But it will take years to replace all of our stock with these new improved products you've invented.
No. It won't. All you have to do is print these words on the packaging. That's it.
Mark changes the slide again: The car dashboard light now reads, "This Car Prevents Crashes", and another slide tha shows a package of meat with a sticker reading, "This Mea Actually Cures Cancer".
Even if you don't understand it, just start shipping these products out to people as you see them here and you're all going to get very, very rich.
How did you do it?
Look, they're still the same products you have on the shelves right now. The only difference now is that people won't get bummed out or scared when they use them. Isn't that a good thing?
The executives all nod their heads in agreement and rise shake Mark's hand.
Gentleman, if you'll excuse me, I have five thousand gay orphans on my front lawn that are going bananas.

We follow a suburban housewife as she pushes her shopping cart through the aisles of a bright and shiny super marke She picks up a six pack of Coke and notices the label: "N Coke -- It Tastes Great! With a full cart the housewife wheels it to the checkout counter to find swarms of people already there, all of th carts bursting to the brim with new, exciting products. Everyone looks excited and happy.

Back at his old stomping ground, Mark sits at the bar by himself drinking coffee and watching the TV. Greg sits next to him, with two boxes of cookies and a li of coke in front of him. Different newspapers are spread out on the bar, all of th with similar headlines, "World Rocked By New Healthy Products", "People Everywhere Line up for Guilt-Free Trea "YOU CAN EAT CAKE -- ALL THE TIME!". The man takes a bite of a Twinkie and wavers a bit like h going to pass out.
Are you all right, sir?
The man steadies himself.
Yeah. I must just be real happy. It says on the wrapper that they help boost your happiness.
The man smiles, but he's obviously not feeling well.
He's watching the TV with a bit of worry on his face. He turns to Greg who is eating a stack of cookies and washin down by gulping from a liter of coke.
You should slow down there, Greg.
Why's that?
Just because the package says it's not bad for you doesn't mean you have to gorge yourself on it.
But it tastes so good.

That's just stupid.
No it's not.
Greg holds up the package of cookies and points to the disclaimer which reads, "These cookies make you smarter".
See?
Mark sighs.
You look sad. Here, have a brownie. They'll cheer you up.
Greg hands Mark a brownie that, sure enough, says "They'l cheer you up!" right on the package.
I wish that worked for me, Greg.
What?
Nevermind. I'll see you around.

Mark drives while we take in a bit of his world, highligh the various changes he's wrought. A homeless man stands on the street corner with a sign th now reads, "Screw it. I'll be in my mansion soon." He has big smile on his face. The same business man pulls up beside Mark's car, this ti eating a giant donut and talking loudly into his cell pho
I'm not talking to anyone on my cell phone. But from a distance I look very important and busy.
At a red light Mark eavesdrops on the same arguing couple
No, I won't move into your mansion with you when we die. You're really smothering me.
The more you push me away, the more attracted I am to you.
A bus passes in front of Mark's car. The ad now reads, "Pepsi. Just As Good as Coke." A car honks behind Mark. The man leans out of his car and yells at Mark.
Move it, fatty!
As the man passes him, he looks at Mark and pulls up besi him.
Hey you're Mark Bellison!
Yeah. So are you going to apologize?
For what?
The honking man speeds away.
Mark sits in front of the gravesite of his grandmother. ANGLE ON: Her tombstone which reads, "Martha Bellison 191 2007. Lived an average life for a woman in her time."

Nothing's really changed. I gave people the Man in the Sky, made myself rich and successful, told the world they can eat whatever they want and feel good about it. Everyone's happy but me. Because I'm the only one who knows it all... isn't. I made it all up. (PAUSE) You're not up there living in a mansion. You're right here. In the ground. That's all. And I'm the only one who knows that. (PAUSE) And the one thing I want I can't have. Because the world is too stupid to change. The world only cares about what they can see, and what they can know, and what they're used to and what... makes sense. No one listens to what they really want. And that's why I'll always just be a loser, grandma. And that's why I'll always be alone.

With a beer bottle in his hand Mark searches through his kitchen drawers for a bottle opener. He opens a drawer an something catches his eye. ANGLE ON: The envelope which reads, "MY INVENTION". Slowly Mark pulls it out of the drawer and stares at it. The sound of his front door opening startles him and Mark shoves the envelope into his back pocket.
Who's there?
It's me. Can I come in?
Sure.
Jennifer enters the kitchen.
Haven't seen you much lately.
I know. I've been busy with work and things. And I'm getting married. That's why I came over. To tell you.
Mark nods.
Don't do it.
The wedding is tomorrow.
Jennifer pulls out an invitation, Mark waves it away.
I hope you'll come.
Mark shrugs and Jennifer puts the invitation back in her purse.
No point really.
It would make me happy. Being around you makes me happy.
Mark turns towards her.
So don't marry him.
I only have a few years to marry someone with good genes and financial stability so I can have children and the family I've always wanted. One day I'll be old and wrinkly and ugly.
No you won't. Not to me you won't. I love you. If you really love someone it doesn't matter what they look like.
What do you mean?
Do me this favor. Just one favor. Don't accept everything you see. Don't just do something because that's the way it's done.
You're confusing me.

Think about what you want. Find out what you really want. And if it's not the same as what I want, well then I'll know that and I'll never darken your doorstep again. (PAUSE) I want you. What do you want?
Jennifer and Mark stare at each other for a long beat.
I'm going to go.
Please don't. Will you just stay a little bit longer? I don't want to be alone. Just sit with me.

Jennifer nods. Mark leads her into the living room and th sit down far apart from each other on the couch. Mark tur the TV on and they both sit in silence. LATER. Mark has fallen asleep on the couch. Jennifer checks her watch and stands up. She takes out her wedding invitation lays it on the coffee table by Mark. She unfolds a blanket and is about to place it on him whe she notices an envelope sticking out of his back pocket. pulls it out and looks at it.
(READING) My invention.
She opens the letter and begins to read. Once finished, s folds up the letter and hurriedly leaves, scared and confused.
Mark wakes up and sees Jennifer's wedding invitation on t coffee table. He sighs.
Mark stands before the mirror, dressed in a suit, putting a tie. Greg pokes his head into the room, dressed in a suit as w
We're gonna be late.
The sign outside reads, "A QUITE PLACE TO THINK ABOUT THE IN THE SKY".
Makes sense people would start getting married at these places. I mean, who you marry decides who's mansion you're going to live in one day. It's a big decision.
Yeah.
They enter the building.

A small stage sits before a large stained glass window portraying Mark holding the two halves of the pizza box. Rob stands at the altar. Mark and Greg take their seats amidst a crowd of people sitting quietly in their chairs.

Jennifer sits in a small room in a beautiful white dress, looking as beautiful as any woman has ever looked. She st absentmindedly out the window. There's a knock at the door. JENNIFER'S MOTHER pokes her in.
It's time, dear.
Jennifer doesn't answer. We PUSH IN on Jennifer to see sh clutching Mark's letter in her hand.
Jennifer?
I don't feel all right.
What's wrong? Do you have food poisoning?
No. I don't think there's a word for what I have.

"Here's comes the Bride" plays over an organ and Jennifer walks down the aisle towards a smiling Rob. Mark watches her in awe, stunned by her beauty. Rob notic Mark staring at Jennifer and mouths "loser" at him.
Jennifer reaches the altar and stands across from Rob. Th WEDDING OVERSEER, an elderly man in a suit, stands betwee them holding a few sheets of paper in his hand.

We are sitting here in this building today to share in the wedding of Rob and Jennifer. Two young, attractive people who have agreed that this union would be mutually beneficial and that their genetic match-up would most likely produce favorable offspring and a life of financial stability and physical security.
Both Rob and Jennifer nod at each other.
Rob, do you promise to stay with Jennifer for as long as you want to and to protect your offspring for as long as you can?
I do.
Jennifer, do you promise to stay with Rob for as long as you want to and to protect your offspring for as long as you can?
Jennifer doesn't respond.
Jennifer?
(to Overseer) I'm sorry, hold on one second. (to Rob) Rob, can I ask you something?
There's a slight hubbub in the room. Mark perks up.
(CONCERNED) Sure. But what are you doing?
What color are my eyes?
I dunno... (LOOKING) Oh, they're brown.
CLOSE ON Jennifer's eyes. Indeed, they are brown.
No Rob, they're blue.
Rob looks again. Mark stirs in his seat, amazed by what h hearing.
Oh, look at that. So they are. You've got pretty blue eyes.
PUSH IN on Jennifer. It works. Her mind is reeling.
Can we get on with this?
Jennifer, do you promise to stay with Rob for as long as you want to and to protect your offspring for as long as you can?
Jennifer is confused. Her mind is fighting it, but she doesn't know what exactly she's fighting. Finally...
I do.
There is a sigh of relief from the room. Mark shakes his in sadness.
Before I pronounce these two man and wife, is there anyone here who thinks they'd offer either of these people a better genetic match-up?
Mark bolts up in his chair.
Me.
The whole room gasps.
Oh come on. Look at you. You can't be better.
Yes I can. You've got shmuck genes.
Schmuck genes? What's that?
And I love her. (to Jennifer) Jennifer, don't marry him. Is this what you really want?
I don't know. (pause; unsure) Yes?
Mark thinks this over for a beat.
All right. I'm done. Goodbye.
Awkwardly Mark makes his way to the aisle and leaves the room. The room is thick with tension.
Are we married yet? Because I've got plans this afternoon.
Mark loosens his tie as he walks out of the building and towards the street. In the background we can see the "church" door open.
(SHOUTING) Hold on a minute!
Mark turns, confused and tired. Jennifer runs to him. She stands before him, they both st at each other.
What?
Jennifer pulls out Mark's letter and shows it to him.
I'm confused.
So am I.
Is any of it... the things you said... are they... I can't think of the word. (PAUSE) Is there a Man in the Sky?
No.
Why'd you say there was?
Because I couldn't cope with the look on my grandmother's face.
But how could you say something that... wasn't.
I'm not sure. I just did it.
And what did you mean that I could grow old and ugly and still be beautiful to you?
I mean just that. You'll always be beautiful to me.
But what if my looks...
It doesn't matter.
I feel funny.
Me too. (PAUSE) Everything is so hard. Nothing is easy anymore.
There is a long moment of silence. Jennifer moves closer Mark and looks directly into his eyes.
I know what I want.
What?
I want short, fat kids with little snub noses.
The biggest smile we've ever seen comes across Mark's fac
Easy! That's an easy one.

Just   like she did the night on her couch, Jennifer reac over   and puts her hand on Mark's wrist. They both stare each   other for a long beat, holding hands, love beaming both   of them. The world is changing before their eyes.
Does anyone else know about your invention?
No. But I'm sure it won't be long.
Should we tell them right away?
I'm not sure. I don't think everyone will understand.
Greg sticks his head out of the church door.
What's going on out here? Everyone's just sitting in there. Are we gonna finish this wedding?
Jennifer smiles at Mark.
Yes.
Mark smiles back.
Praise the Man in the Sky.
WE RISE UP as Mark and Jennifer walk hand in hand towards church -- and an unknowable future.
The world's last moment of honesty. A monumental occasion in the history of mankind.

That lowly writer who stumbled upon the ability to lie went on to become one of the most important men of his age, married to one of the most beautiful women of his time, and passed on the lying gene to generations to come.

A world without honesty is a world with dreams. A world with pretense. A world with fiction. A world with flattery. And most importantly, a world with true love. Put simply, a world very much like our own.
